{{about|the type of [[genre fiction]] involving love and lust|[[literary fiction]] romance novels|Novel|[[Joseph Conrad]]'s novel ''Romance''|Romance (novel)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} {{multiple issues| {{original research|date=January 2018}} {{fansite|date=January 2018}} }} [[File:Hammond-SS10.jpg|thumb|"Oh Edward! How can you?", a late-19th-century illustration from ''[[Sense and Sensibility]]'' (1811) by [[Jane Austen]], a pioneer of the genre ]]
Although the [[genre]] is very old, the '''romance novel''' or '''romantic novel''' discussed in this article is the [[mass-market]] [[genre literature|version]]. [[Novel]]s of this type of [[genre fiction]] place their primary focus on the relationship and [[Romance (love)|romantic love]] between two people, and must have an "emotionally satisfying and optimistic ending."<ref name="rwadefn">{{cite web | title = The Romance Genre Overview | publisher = [[Romance Writers of America]] | url =http://www.rwa.org/p/cm/ld/fid=578 | accessdate = November 26, 2013}}</ref> There are many subgenres of the romance novel, including [[fantasy]], [[historical romance]], [[paranormal fiction]], and [[science fiction]].
The term ''romance'' is also applied to a type of novel defined by [[Walter Scott]] as "a fictitious narrative in prose or verse; the interest of which turns upon marvellous and uncommon incidents".<ref>{{cite news|author=Scott, Walter & Maning, Susan (Editor) |title=Essay on Romance|work=Prose Works|volume= vi|page= 129}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Scott, Walter |title=Introduction|work=Quentin Durand|location= Oxford|publisher= Oxford University Press|date= 1992}}</ref>
A thriving genre of works conventionally referred to as "romance novels" existed in ancient Greece.<ref name="Collected Ancient Greek Novels">{{cite book|last1=Reardon|first1=Bryan P.|title=Collected Ancient Greek Novels|date=1989|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=0-520-04306-5|pages=1–16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MA7rRGBC7IMC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 May 2017}}</ref> Other precursors can be found in the literary fiction of the 18th and 19th centuries, including [[Samuel Richardson]]'s [[sentimental novel]] ''[[Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded]]'' (1740) and the novels of [[Jane Austen]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Regis, Pamela |title=A Natural History of the Romance Novel|publisher= University of Pennsylvania Press|date= 2007}}</ref> Austen inspired [[Georgette Heyer]], the British author of historical romance set around the time Austen lived, as well as [[detective fiction]]. Heyer's first romance novel, ''The Black Moth'' (1921), was set in 1751.
The [[United Kingdom|British]] company [[Mills and Boon]] began releasing [[escapist fiction]] for women in the 1930s. Their books were sold in [[North America]] by [[Harlequin Enterprises Ltd]], which began [[direct marketing]] to readers and allowing [[mass-market]] merchandisers to carry the books.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} <!-- prove it: An early American example of a mass-market romance was [[Kathleen Woodiwiss]]' ''[[The Flame and the Flower]]'' (1972), published by [[Avon Books]]. This was the first single-title romance novel to be published as an original [[paperback]] in the US, though in the UK the romance genre was long established through the works of [[Georgette Heyer]], and from the 1950s [[Catherine Cookson]], as well as others.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} Nancy Coffey was the senior editor who negotiated a multi-book deal with Woodiwiss. The genre boomed in the 1980s, with the addition of many different categories of romance and an increased number of single-title romances, but popular authors started pushing the boundaries of both the genre and plot, as well as creating more contemporary characters.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
In North America, romance novels are the most popular literary genre, comprising almost 55% of all paperback books sold in 2004.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} The genre is also popular in Europe and Australia, and romance novels appear in 90 languages. Most of the books, however, are written by authors from English-speaking countries, leading to an Anglo-Saxon perspective in the fiction.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} Despite the popularity and widespread sales of romance novels, the genre has attracted significant derision, skepticism, and criticism.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} Romance erotica seems to be on the rise as more women explore this new subgenre.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} ''Erotica'' is a term used to describe scenes in the novel that are risqué but not pornographic.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} -->
==Definition== {{rquote|right|Women will pick up a romance novel knowing what to expect, and this foreknowledge of the reader is very important. When the hero and heroine meet and fall in love, maybe they don't know they're in love but the reader does. Then a conflict will draw them apart, but you know in the end they'll be back together, and preferably married or planning to be by page 192.|Joan Schulhafer of Pocket Books, 1982{{r|nyt1982}}}}
According to the [[Romance Writers of America]], the main plot of a mass-market romance novel must revolve about the two people as they develop romantic love for each other and work to build a relationship. Both the conflict and the climax of the novel should be directly related to that core theme of developing a romantic relationship, although the novel can also contain [[subplot]]s that do not specifically relate to the main characters' romantic love. Furthermore, a romance novel must have an "emotionally satisfying and optimistic ending." Others, including Leslie Gelbman, a president of [[Berkley Books]], define the genre more simply, stating only that a romance must make the "romantic relationship between the hero and the heroine ... the core of the book."<ref name="whatsinaname">{{Cite news|title=What's in a Name? |newspaper=Publishers Weekly |date=July 2, 2001 |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/index.asp?layout=article&articleId=CA91257&display=searchResults |accessdate=April 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080212184432/http://www.publishersweekly.com/index.asp?layout=article |archivedate=February 12, 2008 }}</ref> In general, romance novels reward characters who are good people and penalize those who are evil, and a couple who fights for and believes in their relationship will likely be rewarded with unconditional love.<ref name="rwadefn"/> Bestselling author [[Nora Roberts]] sums up the genre, saying: "The books are about the celebration of falling in love and emotion and commitment, and all of those things we really want."<ref name="gray"/> [[Women's fiction]] (including "[[chick lit]]") is not directly a subcategory of the romance novel genre, because in women's fiction the heroine's relationship with her family or friends may be as important as her relationship with the hero.<ref name="whatsinaname"/>
Some romance novel authors and readers believe the genre has additional restrictions, from plot considerations (such as the [[protagonists]]' meeting early on in the story), to avoiding themes (such as [[adultery]]). Other disagreements have centered on the firm requirement for a happy ending; some readers admit stories without a happy ending, if the focus of the story is on the [[Romance (love)|romantic love]] between the two main characters (e.g., ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]''). While the majority of romance novels meet the stricter criteria, there are also many books widely considered to be romance novels that deviate from these rules. Therefore, the general definition, as embraced by the RWA and publishers, includes only the focus on a developing romantic relationship and an optimistic ending.<ref name="crusiedefn">{{Cite journal | first =Jennifer | last =Crusie | author-link =Jennifer Crusie | contribution =I Know What It Is When I Read It: Defining the Romance Genre | contribution-url =http://www.jennycrusie.com/essays/definingromancegenre.php | date =March 2000 | publisher =PAN | title =Romance Writer's Report }}</ref><ref name="dorchester"/> [[Escapism]] is important; an Avon executive observed that "The phone never rings, the baby never cries and the rent's never overdue in romances".{{r|nyt1982}}
As long as a romance novel meets those twin criteria, it can be set in any time period and in any location. There are no specific restrictions on what can or cannot be included in a romance novel.<ref name="rwadefn"/> Even controversial subjects are addressed in romance novels, including topics such as date rape, domestic violence, addiction, and disability.<ref name="whitepamela"/> The combination of time frame, location, and plot elements does, however, help a novel to fit into one of several romance subgenres.<ref name="rwadefn"/> Despite the numerous possibilities this framework allows, many people in the mainstream press claim that "all [romance novels] seem to read alike."<ref name="gold30">{{cite web | last = Gold | first = Laurie | title = Laurie's News and Views - Issue No. 30 | publisher = All About Romance Novels | date = July 30, 1997 | url = http://www.likesbooks.com/30.html | accessdate = April 23, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070211115303/http://www.likesbooks.com/30.html | archivedate = February 11, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Stereotypes of the romance genre abound. For instance, some believe that all romance novels are similar to those of [[Danielle Steel]], featuring rich, glamorous people traveling to exotic locations.<ref name="bellafante">{{Cite news | last = Bellafante | first = Gina | title = Affairs to Remember | newspaper = Time | date = August 8, 1994 | url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,981206,00.html | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref> Many romance readers disagree that Steel writes romance at all, considering her novels more mainstream fiction.<ref name="atthebackfence#197">{{cite web | last = Gold | first = Laurie | title = At the Back Fence Issue #197 | publisher = All About Romance Novels | date = March 1, 2005 | url = http://www.likesbooks.com/197.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070212112905/http://www.likesbooks.com/197.html | archivedate = February 12, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Mass-market romance novels are sometimes referred to as "smut" or female [[pornography]],<ref name="bly">{{Cite news | last = Bly | first = Mary| author-link=Mary Bly | title = A Fine Romance | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = February 12, 2005 | url =http://www.eloisajames.com/images/articles/nyt_op-ed/NYT_ELO_2-12-05.jpg | accessdate = April 16, 2007}}</ref><ref name="faircloth">{{Cite news | last = Faircloth | first = Kelly | title = Who Wrote the Book of Love? | newspaper = The Harvard Independent | date = April 28, 2005 | url = http://www.harvardindependent.com/2005/04/who-wrote-the-book-of-love/ | accessdate = April 23, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120512044517/http://www.harvardindependent.com/2005/04/who-wrote-the-book-of-love/ | archivedate = May 12, 2012 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> and are the most popular form of modern erotica for women.{{r|ogas20110430}} While some romance novels do contain more erotic acts, in other romance novels the characters do no more than kiss chastely. The romance genre runs the spectrum between these two extremes.<ref name="hank">{{cite web | last = Hank | first = Melissa | title = Of supple breasts and manly chests | publisher = TV Guide | date = March 5, 2007 | url = http://entertainment1.sympatico.msn.ca/TV_Guide/Interviews/Features/Articles/050307_romance%20novels_MH | accessdate = April 16, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070403211005/http://entertainment1.sympatico.msn.ca/TV_Guide/Interviews/Features/Articles/050307_romance%20novels_MH | archivedate = April 3, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Because women buy 90% of all romance novels,<ref name="ogas20110430">{{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704463804576291181510459902 | title=The Online World of Female Desire | work=The Wall Street Journal | date=April 30, 2011 | accessdate=May 4, 2011 | author=Ogas, Ogi}}</ref> most romance novels are told from a woman's viewpoint, in either [[first person narrative|first]] or [[third person narrative|third person]].
Although most romance novels are about heterosexual pairings there are romance novels that deal with same-sex relationships, and some participants in the book industry characterize books dealing with same-sex relationships as F/F,<ref>{{cite web|website=Goodreads|url=https://www.goodreads.com/list/tag/f-f|title= Listopia > F F Book Lists}}</ref> and M/M.<ref>{{cite web|website=Goodreads|url=https://www.goodreads.com/list/tag/m-m|title= Listopia > M M Book Lists}}</ref>
==History==
===Development=== [[File:Charles Gleyre - Daphnis et Chloe revenant de la montagne.jpg|thumb|A nineteenth-century painting by the Swiss-French painter [[Charles Gleyre|Marc Gabriel Charles Gleyre]] depicting a scene from [[Longus]]'s ''[[Daphnis and Chloe]]'']]
While this article is about the mass-market form of love romance novels, the genre of works of extended prose fiction dealing with romantic love existed in classical Greece.<ref name="Collected Ancient Greek Novels"/> The titles of over twenty such [[ancient Greek novel|ancient Greek romance novels]] are known, but most of them have only survived in an incomplete, fragmentary form.<ref name="Collected Ancient Greek Novels"/> Only five ancient Greek romance novels have survived to the present day in a state of near-completion: ''[[Chariton|Chareas and Callirhoe]]'', ''[[Leucippe and Clitophon]]'', ''[[Daphnis and Chloe]]'', ''[[Ephesian Tale|The Ephesian Tale]]'', and ''[[Aethiopica|The Ethiopian Tale]]''.<ref name="Collected Ancient Greek Novels"/>
Precursors of the modern popular love-romance can also be found in the [[sentimental novel]] ''[[Pamela, or Virtue Rewarded]],'' by [[Samuel Richardson]], published in 1740. ''Pamela'' was the first popular novel to be based on a courtship as told from the perspective of the heroine. Unlike many of the novels of the time, ''Pamela'' had a happy ending, when after Mr. B attempts unsuccessfully to seduce and rape Pamela multiple times, he eventually rewards her virtue by sincerely proposing an equitable marriage to her. The book was one of the first bestsellers, with five editions printed in the first eleven months of release.<ref>Regis (2003), pp. 63, 64, 66</ref>
[[Jane Austen]] is an important influence on romance [[genre fiction]], and ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'', published in 1813, has been called "the best romance novel ever written".<ref>Regis (2003), p 75.</ref> In the early part of the [[Victorian era]], the [[Brontë|Brontë sisters]], like Austen, wrote [[literary fiction]] that influenced later popular fiction. [[Charlotte Brontë]] in ''[[Jane Eyre]]'', published in 1847, introduced the orphaned heroine. Brontë's love romance incorporates elements of both the [[Gothic fiction|gothic novel]] and [[Elizabethan drama]], and "demonstrate[s] the flexibility of the romance novel form."<ref>Regis (2003), p. 85.</ref>
While the literary fiction romance continued to develop in the 20th century, the new subgenre of genre fiction, which first developed in the 19th century, started to become more popular after the [[First World War]]. In 1919, [[E.M. Hull]]'s novel ''[[The Sheik (novel)|The Sheik]]'' was published in the [[United Kingdom]]. The novel, which became hugely popular, was adapted into a [[The Sheik (film)|movie]] (1921), which established star [[Rudolph Valentino]] as the top male actor of the time. The hero of this book was an iconic [[alpha male]] who kidnapped the heroine and won her admiration through his forceful actions. The novel was one of the first modern works to introduce the [[rape fantasy]], a theme explored in Samuel Richardson's ''Pamela'' (1740). Although women were gaining more independence in life, publishers believed that readers would only accept premarital sex in the context of rape. In this novel and those that followed, the rape was depicted as more of a fantasy; the heroine is rarely if ever shown experiencing terror, stress, or trauma as a result.<ref>Regis (2003), pp. 115–117.</ref>
The popular, mass market version of the [[historical novel|historical romance]], which [[Walter Scott]] developed in the early 19th century, is seen as beginning in 1921, when [[Georgette Heyer]] published ''The Black Moth''. This is set in 1751, but many of Heyer's novels were inspired by Jane Austen's novels and are set around the time Austen lived, in the later [[Regency period]]. Because Heyer's romances are set more than 100 years earlier, she includes carefully researched historical detail to help her readers understand the period.<ref>Regis (2003), pp. 125-126.</ref> Unlike other popular love-romance novels of the time, Heyer's novels used the setting as a major plot device. Her characters often exhibit twentieth century sensibilities, and more conventional characters in the novels point out the heroine's eccentricities, such as wanting to marry for love.<ref>Regis (2003), p. 127.</ref> Heyer was a prolific author, and wrote one to two historical romance novels per year until her death in 1974.<ref>Regis (2003), p 125.</ref>
===Rise of the category romance=== In the 1930s, the British publishers [[Mills and Boon]] began releasing hardback romance novels. The books were sold through weekly two-penny libraries and were known as "the books in brown" for their brown binding. In the 1950s, the company began offering the books for sale through newsagents across the United Kingdom.<ref name="mandb">{{cite web|title=Mills & Boon - Our History|url=http://www.millsandboon.co.uk/cgi-bin/millsandboon.filereader?461262c700a12d24273f58d0dc9e068f+EN/catalogs/1124|publisher=Harlequin Mills and Boon|accessdate=July 19, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013164823/http://millsandboon.co.uk/cgi-bin/millsandboon.filereader?461262c700a12d24273f58d0dc9e068f+EN%2Fcatalogs%2F1124|archivedate=October 13, 2007|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A Canadian company, [[Harlequin Enterprises]], began distributing in North America in 1957 the category romances published by Mills and Boon.<ref name="Thurston 1987, p. 42">Thurston (1987), p. 42.</ref> Mary Bonneycastle, wife of Harlequin founder Richard Bonneycastle, and her daughter, Judy Burgess, exercised editorial control over which Mills and Boon novels Harlequin reprinted. They had a "decency code," and rejected more sexually explicit material that Mills and Boon submitted for reprinting. Realizing that the genre was popular, Richard Bonneycastle finally decided to read a romance novel. He chose one of the more explicit novels and enjoyed it. On his orders, the company conducted a market test with the novel he had read and discovered that it outsold a similar, tamer novel.<ref>Regis (2003), p. 185</ref> Overall, the novels were short and formulaic, featuring heroines who were sweet, compassionate, pure and innocent. The few heroines who worked did so in traditional female jobs, including as [[nurse]]s, [[governess]]es and [[secretary|secretaries]]. Intimacy in the novels never extended beyond a chaste kiss between the protagonists.<ref name="Thurston 1987, p. 42"/>
On October 1, 1971, Harlequin purchased Mills and Boon. By this point, the romance novel genre "had been popularized and distributed widely to an enthusiastic audience" in [[Great Britain]]. In an attempt to duplicate Mills and Boon's success in North America, Harlequin improved their distribution and marketing system.<ref name="Regis 2003, p. 156">Regis (2003), p. 156.</ref> By choosing to sell their books "where the women are," they allowed many mass-market merchandisers and even supermarkets to sell the books, all of which were exactly 192 pages. Harlequin then began a reader service, selling directly to readers who agreed to purchase a certain number of books each month.<ref>Thurston, pp. 46-47.</ref>
===<span id="Birth of modern romance"></span>The beginnings of American romance fiction=== In the US, modern romance genre fiction was born in 1972, with [[Avon Books|Avon's]] publication of [[Kathleen Woodiwiss]]'s ''[[The Flame and the Flower]]'', which was the first of the modern "bodice ripper" romance novels to follow "the principals into the bedroom."<ref name="athitakis">{{Cite news | last = Athitakis | first = Mark | title = A Romance Glossary | newspaper = SF Weekly | date = July 25, 2001 | url =http://www.sfweekly.com/2001-07-25/news/a-romance-glossary/ | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref><ref name="zaitchik"/> Aside from its content, the book was revolutionary in that it was one of the first single-title romance novels to be published as an original [[paperback]], rather than being first published in [[hardcover]], and, like the category romances, was distributed in drug stores and other mass-market merchandising outlets.<ref name="thurston4748"/> The novel went on to sell 2.35 million copies.<ref name="darrach">{{Cite news | last =Darrach | first =Brad | title = Rosemary's Babies | newspaper = Time| date = January 17, 1977 | url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,918604-2,00.html|accessdate=July 17, 2007}}</ref> Avon followed its release with the 1974 publication of Woodiwiss's second novel, ''The Wolf and the Dove'' and two more sexually graphic novels by newcomer [[Rosemary Rogers]], ''Sweet Savage Love'' and ''Dark Fires''. The latter sold two million copies in its first three months of release. By 1975, ''Publishers Weekly'' had reported that the "Avon originals" had sold a combined {{nowrap|8 million copies}}.<ref name="thurston4748">Thurston, pp 47-48.</ref> The following year over 150 historical romance novels, many of them paperback originals, were published, selling over {{nowrap|40 million copies}}.<ref name="darrach"/>
The success of these novels prompted a new style of writing romance, concentrating primarily on historical fiction tracking the monogamous relationship between a helpless heroine and the hero who rescued her, even if he had been the one to place her in danger.<ref name="whitepamela">{{Cite news | last = White | first = Pamela | title = Romancing Society | newspaper = Boulder Weekly | date = August 15, 2002 | url = http://www.boulderweekly.com/archive/081502/coverstory.html | accessdate = April 23, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070904133155/http://www.boulderweekly.com/archive/081502/coverstory.html | archivedate = September 4, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> The covers of these novels tended to feature scantily clad women being grabbed by the hero, and caused the novels to be referred to as '''bodice-rippers'''.<ref name="athitakis"/> A ''[[Wall St. Journal]]'' article in 1980 referred to these bodice rippers as "publishing's answer to the Big Mac: They are juicy, cheap, predictable, and devoured in stupefying quantities by legions of loyal fans."<ref>Thurston, p 67.</ref> The term ''bodice-ripper'' is now considered offensive to many in the romance industry.<ref name="athitakis"/>
In this new style of historical romance, heroines were independent and strong-willed and were often paired with heroes who evolved into caring and compassionate men who truly admired the women they loved.<ref>Thurston, p 72.</ref> This was in contrast to the contemporary romances published during this time, which were often characterized by weak females who fell in love with overbearing [[alpha male]]s.<ref name="grossman"/> Although these heroines had active roles in the plot, they were "passive in relationships with the heroes."<ref name="crusie"/> Across the genre, heroines during this time were usually aged 16–21, with the heroes slightly older, usually around 30. The women were [[virgins]], while the men were not, and both members of the couple were described as beautiful.<ref>Thurston, p 75.</ref>
===Category romance adapts=== Category romance lines were slower to react to some of the changes that had swept the historical romance subgenre. Despite the fact that the former Mills & Boon lines were now owned by a [[North America]]n company, the lines did not have any American writers until 1975, when Harlequin purchased a novel by [[Janet Dailey]].<ref>Thurston (1987), pp. 46-47.</ref><ref>Regis (2003), pp. 155–156</ref> Dailey's novels provided the romance genre's "first look at heroines, heroes and courtships that take place in America, with American sensibilities, assumptions, history, and most of all, settings."<ref>Regis (2003), p. 159.</ref> Harlequin was unsure how the market would react to this new type of romance, and was unwilling to fully embrace it. In the late 1970s, a Harlequin editor rejected a manuscript by [[Nora Roberts]], who has since become the top-selling romance author, because "they already had their American writer."<ref>Regis (2003), pp. 158, 183, 184.</ref>
Harlequin sold almost $70 million of its paperback romances in 1979 through 100,000 supermarkets and other stores, giving the company almost 10% of the market for paperback books. That year the company began distributing its own books in the United States instead of through [[Simon & Schuster]]'s [[Pocket Books]]. In 1980 Simon & Schuster formed Silhouette Books to publish its own romance novels, beginning what ''The New York Times'' called "perhaps the most bitter war in American book publishing history".<ref name="walters19801012">{{cite news | title=Paperback Talk | work=The New York Times | date=October 12, 1980 | author=Walters, Ray | pages=A47}}</ref> The company sought to take advantage of the untapped talent of the American writers.<ref>Regis (2003), pp. 156, 159.</ref> They published several lines of category romance, and encouraged their writers to create stronger heroines and less dominant heroes. Authors were also expected to address contemporary issues where appropriate.<ref>Regis (2003), p. 184</ref> Silhouette soon saw their market share expand, and in 1984, Harlequin acquired them. Despite the acquisition, Silhouette continued to retain editorial control and to publish various lines under their own imprint.<ref name="Regis 2003, p. 156"/>
Harlequin had also failed to adapt quickly to the signs that readers appreciated novels with more explicit sex scenes, and in 1980, several publishers entered the category romance market to fill that gap. That year, Dell launched their Candlelight Ecstasy line with [[Amii Lorin]]'s ''The Tawny Gold Man'', becoming the first line to waive the requirement that heroines be virgins. By the end of 1983 sales for the Candlelight Ecstasy line totaled $30 million. Silhoeutte also launched similar lines, Desire (sexually explicit) and Special Edition (sexually explicit and longer stories, up to 250 pages), each of which had a 90–100% sellout rate each month.<ref name="barret">{{Cite news | last =Barrett | first =Mary Ellin | title =Pure as the Driven Slush | newspaper =Family Weekly | date =January 9, 1983 | url =http://www.cherylclarke.net/cherylclarke.net%20folder/cherylclarke.net/pdf_files/Binder%203.pdf | format =PDF | accessdate =May 24, 2007 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070927004649/http://www.cherylclarke.net/cherylclarke.net%20folder/cherylclarke.net/pdf_files/Binder%203.pdf | archivedate =September 27, 2007 | df =mdy-all }}</ref>
A 1982 survey of romance readers confirmed that the new styles of writing were attracting new readers to the genre. 35% of the readers surveyed had begun reading romances after 1977. An additional 31% of those surveyed had been readers for between 6 and 10 years, meaning they had become interested in the genre after 1972, when Woodiwiss's revolutionary novel was published. This means that two-thirds of those surveyed joined the genre after it had begun to change.<ref>Thurston, pp. 127-128.</ref>
The number of category romance lines increased at a rapid pace, and by 1985 there were 16 separate lines producing a total of 80 novels per month.<ref>Regis (2003), p. 157.</ref> The sudden increase in category romance lines meant an equally sudden increase in demand for writers of the new style of romance novel. This tight market caused a proportionate decrease in the quality of the novels that were being released. By 1984, the market was saturated with category lines and readers had begun to complain of redundancy in plots.<ref>Thurston, p 188.</ref> The following year, the "dampening effect of the high level of redundancy associated with series romances was evident in the decreased number of titles being read per month."<ref>Thurston, p 128.</ref> Harlequin's return rate, which had been less than 25% in 1978, when it was the primary provider of category romance, swelled to 60%.<ref>Thurston, p 190.</ref>
===Further change=== The genre continued to expand in the mid-to-late 1980s, as publishers realized that the more popular authors were often those who stretched the boundaries of the genre. A 1984 novel by [[LaVyrle Spencer]] featured an overweight, middle-aged hero who had to make drastic changes to his lifestyle to win the heroine, while a 1987 Dailey novel involved an ugly hero and a heroine who was searching for her birth mother.<ref>Thurston, p 109.</ref> [[Jayne Ann Krentz]]'s 1986 novel ''Sweet Starfire'' became the first futuristic romance, combining elements of traditional romance novels and [[science fiction]].<ref name="gelsomino">{{cite web|last=Gelsomino|first=Tara|title=Review of Smoke in Mirrors|url=http://www.romantictimes.com/books_review.php?cameo=1&book=14972|publisher=Romantic Times|year=2002|accessdate=July 26, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071004201147/http://www.romantictimes.com/books_review.php?cameo=1&book=14972 |archivedate = October 4, 2007}}</ref> The relationships had also modernized: by the 1990s, it was rare to see a book that featured a man raping his future wife.<ref name="grossman">{{Cite news | last =Grossman | first =Lev | author-link =Lev Grossman | title =Rewriting the Romance | newspaper =Time | date =February 3, 2003 | url =http://www.juliaquinn.com/images/news/time-specific/time-magazine/JuliaQuinn.pdf | format =PDF | accessdate =April 3, 2007 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070712042909/http://www.juliaquinn.com/images/news/time-specific/time-magazine/JuliaQuinn.pdf | archivedate =July 12, 2007 | df =mdy-all }}</ref> In the mid-to-late 1980s, contemporary romances began to feature women in more male-dominated jobs, such as offshore oil rigs and the space program. The age range of heroines also began to expand, so that books began to feature women who had already reached 30 and even 40. Heroes also changed, with some authors veering towards a more sensitive man. Despite the broadening of some aspects of the plot, other taboos remained, and publishers discouraged authors from writing about controversial subjects such as terrorism, warfare, and masculine sports.<ref name="ew1991">{{Cite news|title=Rules of the Game|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,315222,00.html|newspaper=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=August 16, 1991|accessdate=July 19, 2007|first=Sarah|last=Bird}}</ref> Romance novels began to contain more humor beginning in the 1990s, as [[Julie Garwood]] began introducing a great deal of humor into her historical romances.<ref name="arr">{{cite web|title=Susan Wiggs - And Now (as usual), Something New|publisher=All About Romance Novels|url=http://www.likesbooks.com/susanwiggs.html|date=May 25, 2003|accessdate=July 25, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928010904/http://www.likesbooks.com/susanwiggs.html|archivedate=September 28, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
The romance novel began to expand in other ways as well.<ref name="park"/> In 1989, author [[Jude Deveraux]] became the first romance author to transition from writing original mass market paperbacks to being published in hardcover. Her novel, ''A Knight in Shining Armor'', "became a natural bestseller."<ref name="whatsinaname"/> Several authors found success writing single-title romances set in contemporary times, and publishing houses began to encourage the growth in the genre. Because the novels were set in modern times, they could include more of the elements that modern women could relate to, and soon began to touch on themes such as single parenthood, adoption, and abuse.<ref name="park">{{cite news | last = Park | first = Michael Y. | title = Reading True Romance | publisher = Fox News | date = August 28, 2002 | url =http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,61370,00.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007}}</ref>
By 2000, the covers had begun to evolve from featuring a scantily clad couple to instead showing a view of the landscape featured in the novel.<ref name="whatsinaname"/>
As women's career options have expanded in real life, so have those of their fictional counterparts. In the earliest Harlequin romance novels, heroines were typically nurses and secretaries. As time has passed and women have entered the workforce in larger numbers, romance heroines have spanned the career spectrum.<ref name="witmer">{{cite web | last = Witmer | first = Karyn | title = Of Books and Baby Boomers | publisher = All About Romance | date = August 28, 2006 | url = http://www.likesbooks.com/236.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070714090837/http://www.likesbooks.com/236.html | archivedate = July 14, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Modern romance novels now feature more balanced relationships between men and women.<ref name="whitepamela"/>
==Critical attention==
The romance genre has been popularly derided and critically ignored.
Despite recent rehabilitation and merging of the genre with other genres, the stigma attached to the romance genre continues to be strong, with some dedicated readers embarrassed to admit to buying or even reading the books.<ref name="gray">{{Cite news| last = Gray | first = Paul | title = Passion on the Pages | newspaper = Time | date = March 20, 2000 | url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,996381,00.html | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref> The romance genre has over the years generated significant derision, skepticism and criticism. Some critics point to a lack of suspense, as it is obvious that the hero and heroine will eventually resolve their issues, and wonder whether it is beneficial "for women to be whiling away so many hours reading impossibly glamorized love stories."<ref name="gray"/> According to fiction author Melissa Pritchard, a romance novel "perpetuates something slightly dangerous, that there's this notion, that there's this perfect love out there, and it can distract you from the work of loving yourself."<ref name="hall">{{Cite news | last = Hall | first = Melissa Mia | title = Wickedly Savage Passions | newspaper = Publishers Weekly | date = February 23, 2004 | url = http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA385469.html?q=%22romance+novel%22 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071113130510/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA385469.html?q=%22romance+novel%22 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = November 13, 2007 | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Romance novelists attribute the stigma to the fact that romance is the only genre "written almost exclusively by women for women."<ref name="gray"/> Romance novelist [[Jennifer Crusie]] counters that in the modern romance novel "a woman is rewarded with unconditional love [only] if she remains true to herself",<ref name="crusie">{{Cite book | isbn =9780879727772 | first =Jennifer | last =Crusie | author-link =Jennifer Crusie | editor-last =Kaler | editor-first =Anne | editor2-last =Johnson-Kurek | editor2-first =Rosemary | chapter =This Is Not Your Mother's Cinderella: The Romance Novel as Feminist Fairy Tale | chapter-url =http://www.jennycrusie.com/essays/thisisnotyourmothers.php | title =Romantic Conventions | year =1998 | pages =51–61 | publisher =Bowling Green Press | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20090202091538/http://jennycrusie.com/essays/thisisnotyourmothers.php | archivedate =February 2, 2009 | df =mdy-all }}</ref> while novelist [[Susan Elizabeth Phillips]] believes that romance novels are popular because the heroine always wins, sometimes overcoming great odds so that she is no longer a victim.<ref name="leopold"/>
==Formats== <!--[[File:Thetawnygoldman.jpg|thumb|right|Note the number 1 in the upper right corner, indicating that this book was the first release in the Dell Candlelight Ecstasy category.{{Deletable image-caption|Friday, January 14, 2011|date=March 2012}}]]--> Romance novels are divided into two sub-sets, category romances, also known as series romances, and single title romances.<ref name="rwadefn"/> Many authors write only within one of the formats, but others, including [[Jennifer Crusie]] and [[Jayne Ann Krentz]], have achieved success in both formats.<ref name="pubweekly">{{Cite news|last=Eykelhof |first=Paula |last2=Macomber |first2=Debbie |author2-link=Debbie Macomber |title=Romancing the Store |newspaper=Publishers Weekly |date=July 31, 2006 |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6357303.html |accessdate=April 16, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113130535/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA6357303.html |archivedate=November 13, 2007 }}</ref>
===Category romance=== [[File:Collection Nocturne de Harlequin.jpg|thumb|150px|Harlequin novels]] Category romances are short, usually no more than 200 pages, or about 55,000 words.<ref name="hamilton">{{cite web | last = Hamilton | first = Melissa | title = Romance Categories: The Different Kinds of Romance | publisher = Romance Ever After | url =http://www.romanceeverafter.com/Romance%20Categories%20-%20The%20Different%20Types%20of%20Romance.htm | accessdate = April 16, 2007}}</ref><ref name=regis160>Regis (2003), p. 160.</ref> The books are published in clearly delineated lines, with a certain number of books published in each line every month. In many cases, the books are numbered sequentially within the line.<ref name="rwadefn"/> These novels have widespread distribution—often worldwide—and a single U.S. print run, remaining on a bookseller's shelves until they are sold out or until the next month's titles are released and take their place.<ref name="pubweekly"/> Writers for the largest publisher of category romance, [[Harlequin Enterprises Ltd|Harlequin/Mills & Boon]], can find their novels translated into 26 languages and sold in over 100 international markets.<ref name="rna">{{cite web | title = About Romantic Fiction | publisher = Romance Novelists' Association| url =http://www.rna-uk.org/index.php?page=romanticfiction | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref>
To write a successful novel of this length, the "author must pare the story down to its essentials. Subplots and minor characters are eliminated or relegated to the backstory."<ref name=regis160/> Nonetheless, category romance lines each have a distinct identity, which may involve similar settings, characters, time periods, levels of sensuality, or types of conflict. Publishers of category romances usually issue guidelines for each line, specifying the elements necessary for a novel to be included in each line.<ref name="eykelhof">{{cite web | last = Eykelhof | first = Paula | title = Writing Guidelines: Harlequin Everlasting Love | publisher = eHarlequin.com | url =http://www.eharlequin.com/articlepage.html?articleId=1086&chapter=0 | accessdate = April 16, 2007}}</ref><ref name="Jeglinski">{{cite web | last = Jeglinski | first = Melissa| title = Writing Guidelines: Silhouette Desire | publisher = eHarlequin.com | url =http://www.eharlequin.com/articlepage.html?articleId=553&chapter=0 | accessdate = April 16, 2007}}</ref><ref name=toth519>Toth (1998), p. 519.</ref> Depending on the current market and perceived reader preferences, publishers frequently begin new lines or end existing ones. Most recently, erotic and [[Christian]] lines have been introduced while traditional [[Regency romance]] lines have ended.<ref name="rwaindstat">{{cite web | title = Industry Statistics | publisher = [[Romance Writers of America]] | year = 2008 | url = http://www.rwanational.org/cs/the_romance_genre/romance_literature_statistics/industry_statistics | accessdate = July 23, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100723013021/http://www.rwanational.org/cs/the_romance_genre/romance_literature_statistics/industry_statistics | archivedate = July 23, 2010 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
===Single-title romances=== Single-titles novels are romance novels not published as part of a publisher's category. They are longer than category romances, typically between 350 and 400 pages, or 100,000-110,000 words.<ref name="hamilton"/> Publishers may release the novels over a shorter period of time for sales and publicity reasons, but on average authors write 1.5 novels per year and have one each year published.<ref name="whatsinaname"/><ref name="rwaauthorstat">{{cite web | title = Author Statistics | publisher = [[Romance Writers of America]] | date = | url =http://eweb.rwanational.org/eweb/DynamicPage.aspx?Site=rwa&WebKey=7e2a43e2-6200-4323-8036-1e8890305b7a | accessdate = July 23, 2010}}</ref> Single-title novels remain on the booksellers' shelves at the discretion of the store.<ref name="leopold">{{cite news | last = Leopold | first = Todd | title = Writing from the heart | publisher = [[CNN]]|date = August 11, 2000 | url =http://archives.cnn.com/2000/books/news/08/11/romance.writers/index.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007}}</ref>
Despite their name, single-title novels are not always stand alone novels. Some authors prefer to write several interconnected books, ranging in number from trilogies to long-running series, so that they can revisit characters or worlds. Such sets of books often have similar titles, and may be labelled as "Number 1 in the XXX Series", but they are not considered series romances because they are not part of a particular line.<ref name="wardbly">{{cite web | last = Ward | first = Jean Marie | title = Eloisa James: Regencies with a Shakespearean Twist | publisher = Crescent Blues| url =http://www.crescentblues.com/8_5issue/int_james.shtml | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref>
==Subgenres== {| align="right" border="1" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="2" class="wikitable" |+ Subgenre Popularity in the United States (2006)<ref name=2006statoverview>{{cite web|url=http://www.rwanational.org/cs/the_romance_genre/romance_literature_statistics|publisher=[[Romance Writers of America]]|title=Romance Literature Statistics: Overview|year=2007|accessdate=November 29, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223085813/http://www.rwanational.org/cs/the_romance_genre/romance_literature_statistics|archivedate=December 23, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |- ! style="background:#efefef;" |Subgenre ! style="background:#efefef;align:center" |% of market |- |Category romance | align="center" |40% |- |Historical romance | align="center" |17% |- |Contemporary romance | align="center" |16% |- |Paranormal romance | align="center" |9% |- |Romantic suspense | align="center" |7% |- |Inspirational romance | align="center" |6% |- |All others | align="center" |5% |} Because the definition of a romance novel does not limit the types of plot devices, time frames, or locations that can be included, the genre has grown to encompass a wide variety of material and spawned multiple subgenres. Subgenres of romance are often closely related to other literature genres, and some books could be considered a romance subgenre novel and another genre novel at the same time. For example, romantic suspense novels are often similar to [[detective fiction|mysteries]], [[crime fiction]] and [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]]s, and [[paranormal romance]]s use elements popular in [[science fiction]] and [[fantasy]] novels.
===Contemporary romance=== {{Main article|Contemporary romance}} Contemporary romance, which is set after [[World War II]],<ref name="rwasub">{{cite web | title = Romance Literature Subgenres | publisher = [[Romance Writers of America]] | url = http://www.rwanational.org/cs/romance_literature_subgenres | accessdate = July 23, 2010 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100727064017/http://www.rwanational.org/cs/romance_literature_subgenres | archive-date = July 27, 2010 | dead-url = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> is often what people mean when they refer to a romance novel. Contemporary romance novels—the largest subgenre—are set in the time when they are written, and usually reflect the mores of that time. Heroines in contemporary romances prior to 1970 usually quit working when they marry or have children—while heroines after 1970 usually have, and keep, a career.<ref name=ramsdell43>Ramsdell (1999), p. 43.</ref> As contemporary romance novels have grown to contain more complex plotting and more realistic characters, the line between this subgenre and the genre of women's fiction has blurred.<ref name=ramsdell44/>
Most contemporary romance novels contain elements that date the books. The majority of them eventually become irrelevant to more modern readers and go out of print.<ref name=ramsdell44>Ramsdell (1999), p. 44.</ref> Those that survive the test of time, such as [[Jane Austen]]'s work, are often reclassified as historical romances.<ref name=ramsdell43/>
Over half of the romantic fiction published in the United States in 2004 (1468 out of 2,285 books) were contemporary romance novels.<ref name="rwastat"/> Contemporary romance novels have twice been chosen by [[Kelly Ripa]] to be featured in her Reading with Ripa book club.<ref name="2003massmarket">{{Cite news|title=The Year in Books 2003: Mass Market |newspaper=[[Publishers Weekly]] |date=November 17, 2003 |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA336202.html?q=paranormal+romance+genre |accessdate=April 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113130500/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA336202.html?q=paranormal+romance+genre |archivedate=November 13, 2007 }}</ref>
===Historical romance=== {{Main article|Historical romance}}
Historical romance, also known as [[historical novel]], is a broad category of [[fiction]] which the plot takes place in a setting located in the past, which [[Walter Scott]] helped popularize in the early 19th-century, with works such as ''[[Rob Roy (novel)|Rob Roy]]'' and ''[[Ivanhoe]]''.<ref>{{Citation | author-link = Rupert Christiansen | last = Christiansen | first = Rupert | origyear = 1988, Bodley Head, {{ISBN|0-37031117-5}}. Paperback reprints, Cardinal, 1989 {{ISBN|0-7474-0404-6}}; Vintage, 1994. {{ISBN|0-09936711-4}} | title = Romantic Affinities: Portraits From an Age, 1780–1830 | place = London | format = paperback | edition = reprint | publisher = Pimlico | year = 2004 | ISBN = 1-84413421-0 | pages = 192–96}}.</ref> [[Literary fiction]] historical romances continue to be published, and a notable recent example is ''[[Wolf Hall]]'' (2009), a multi-award-winning novel by English [[historical novel]]ist [[Hilary Mantel]]. However, the focus here is on the [[mass-market]] genre.
This subgenre includes a wide variety of other subgenres, including [[Regency romance]]. Mass-market historical romance novels are rarely published in hardcover, with fewer than 15 receiving that status each year, less than one-fifth of the number of contemporary romance novels published in that format. Because historical romances are primarily published in mass-market format, their fortunes are tied to a certain extent to the mass-market trends. Booksellers and large merchandisers now sell fewer mass market paperbacks, preferring trade paperbacks or hardcovers, which prevents historical romances from being sold in some price clubs and other mass merchandise outlets.<ref name="dyer"/>
In 2001, 778 mass-market historical romances were published, a 10-year high. By 2004, the annual number had dropped to 486, which was still 20% of all romance novels published. Kensington Books says they receive fewer submissions of historical novels, and their previously published authors have switched to contemporary.<ref name="rwastat"/><ref name="dyer">{{Cite news|last=Dyer |first=Lucinda |title=Romance: In Its Own Time |newspaper=Publishers Weekly |date=June 13, 2005 |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA607853.html?industryid=23602&industry=Romance+Books&q=paranormal+romance+genre |accessdate=April 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113130516/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA607853.html?industryid=23602&industry=Romance+Books&q=paranormal+romance+genre |archivedate=November 13, 2007 }}</ref>
===Romantic suspense=== Romantic suspense involves an intrigue or mystery for the protagonists to solve.<ref name="rwasub"/> Typically, however, the heroine is the victim of a crime or attempted crime, and works with a hero, who tends to be in a field where he would serve as a protector, such as a police officer, [[FBI|FBI agent]], bodyguard, or [[Navy SEAL]].<ref name="textintransit"/><ref name="day">{{Cite news | last = Day | first = Michele | title = Love stories with suspense, humor top charts | newspaper = The Enquirer (Cincinnati, Ohio) | date = August 13, 2002 | url =http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2002/08/13/tem_love_stories_with.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007}}</ref> By the end of the novel, the mystery is resolved and the interaction between the hero and heroine has evolved into a solid relationship.<ref name="textintransit">{{cite web | title = Romantic Suspense | work = Text in Transit: A guide to genre in Popular Literature | publisher = The Canada Research Chair Humanities Computing Studio | date = May 21, 2005 | url = http://www.crcstudio.arts.ualberta.ca/textintransit/viewtext.php?s=browse&tid=123 | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080527224440/http://www.crcstudio.arts.ualberta.ca/textintransit/viewtext.php?s=browse&tid=123 | archivedate = May 27, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> These novels primarily take place in contemporary times, but authors such as [[Amanda Quick]] have broadened the genre to also include historical timeframes.<ref name="marble">{{cite web | last = Marble | first = Anne M. | title = The Subgenres of Romance | publisher = Writing-World.Com | year = 2001 | url =http://www.writing-world.com/romance/romgenres.shtml| accessdate = April 30, 2007}}</ref>
Like all romances, romantic suspense novels must place the development of a relationship between the protagonists at the heart of the story. The relationship "must impact each decision they make and increase the tension of the suspense as it propel the story. In turn, the events of suspense must also directly affect the relationship and move the story forward."<ref name="clayton">{{cite web|last=Clayton |first=Becci |title=My Heroine is in Love With the Killer! Romantic Suspense 101 |publisher=Heart of Denver Romance Writers |url=http://www.hodrw.com/romsuspense101.htm |accessdate=July 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929000523/http://www.hodrw.com/romsuspense101.htm |archivedate=September 29, 2007 }}</ref> Romantic suspense novels tend to have more "clean" language, without the "emotional, intimate" descriptions often used in more traditional romances.<ref name="clayton"/> Because the mystery is a crucial aspect of the plot, these novels are more plot-driven instead of character-driven.<ref name="clayton"/>
This blend of the romance and mystery was perfected by [[Mary Stewart (novelist)|Mary Stewart]], who wrote ten romantic suspense novels between 1955 and 1967. Stewart was one of the first to seamlessly combine the two genres, maintaining a full mystery while focusing on the courtship between two people.<ref>Regis (2003), pp. 143, 144.</ref> In her novels, the process of solving the mystery "helps to illuminate" the hero's personality, helping the heroine to fall in love with him.<ref>Regis (2003), p. 146.</ref>
===Paranormal romance=== {{Main article|Paranormal romance}} Paranormal romance blends the real with the fantastic or science fictional. The fantastic elements may be woven into an alternate version of our own world in an [[urban fantasy]] involving [[vampire]]s, demons, and/or werewolves, or they may be more "normal" manifestations of the paranormal—humans with psychic abilities, witches, or [[ghost]]s. [[Time travel]], futuristic, and extraterrestrial romances also fall beneath the paranormal umbrella.<ref name="rwasub"/><ref name="paranormaldefn">{{cite web | title = Paranormal Romance | work = Text in Transit: A guide to genre in Popular Literature | publisher = The Canada Research CHair Humanities Computing Studio | date = May 25, 2004 | url = http://www.crcstudio.arts.ualberta.ca/textintransit/viewtext.php?s=browse&tid=58 | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20080512103028/http://www.crcstudio.arts.ualberta.ca/textintransit/viewtext.php?s=browse&tid=58 | archivedate = May 12, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
These novels often blend elements of other subgenres—including suspense, mystery, or chick lit—with their fantastic themes.<ref name="arthur">{{cite web | last = Arthur | first = Keri | title = Paranormal Romance and Urban Fantasy—defining two popular subgenres | publisher = The Romance Writers of Australia | year = 2007 | url = http://www.romanceaustralia.com/articles/urban.htm | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070422235749/http://www.romanceaustralia.com/articles/urban.htm | archivedate = April 22, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> A few paranormal romances are set solely in the past and are structured much like any historical romance novel. Others are set in the future, sometimes on different worlds. Still others have a time-travel element with either the hero or the heroine traveling into the past or the future.<ref name="dorchester">{{cite web | title = Submission Guidelines | publisher = Dorchester Publishing | url = http://www.dorchesterpub.com/Dorch/SubmissionGuidlines.cfm | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070430230010/http://www.dorchesterpub.com/Dorch/SubmissionGuidlines.cfm | archivedate = April 30, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Between 2002 and 2004, the number of paranormal romances published in the United States doubled to 170 per year. A popular title in the genre can sell over 500,000 copies.<ref name="luscombe">{{Cite news | last = Luscombe | first = Belinda | title = Well, Hello, Suckers |newspaper= Time | date = February 19, 2006 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1161234,00.html | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref>
Many paranormal romances rely on the blend of contemporary American life with the existence of supernatural or magically empowered beings, human or otherwise. Sometimes the larger culture is aware of the magical in its midst; sometimes it is not. Some paranormal romances focus less on the specifics of their [[Parallel universes in fiction|alternate worlds]] than do traditional science fiction or fantasy novels, keeping the attention strongly on the underlying romance.<ref name="marble"/> Others develop the [[Alternative universe (fan fiction)|alternate reality]] meticulously, combining well-planned magical systems and inhuman cultures with contemporary reality.
===Science fiction romance=== The first futuristic romance to be marketed by a mainstream romance publisher, [[Jayne Ann Krentz]]'s ''Sweet Starfire'', was published in 1986 and was a "classic road trip romance" that just happened to be set in a separate galaxy.<ref name="gelsomino"/> This genre has become more popular since 2000. Krentz attributes the popularity of this romance genre to the fact that the novels "are, at heart, classic historical romances that just happen to be set on other worlds."<ref name="gelsomino"/>
===Fantasy romance=== {{Main article|Romantic fantasy}}
Fantasy Romance, also known as Romantic Fantasy, is a [[Genre|subgenre]] of [[fantasy fiction]], describing a fantasy story using many of the elements and conventions of the romance genre. Romantic fantasy has been published by both fantasy and romance lines, with some publishers distinguishing between "fantasy romance" being more like a contemporary fantasy novel with romantic elements, and "romantic fantasy" with more emphasis on the romance elements of the story.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://web.utk.edu/~wrobinso/590_lec_fan.html | title=A Few Thoughts on the Fantasy Genre | author=William C. Robinson | accessdate=January 18, 2009 | date=October 2004 | publisher=University of Tennessee, Knoxville}}</ref>
===Time-travel romances=== {{main|Time-travel romance}} Time-travel romances are a version of the classic "fish out of water" story. In most, the heroine is from the present day and travels into the past to meet the hero. In a smaller subset of these novels, the hero, who lives in the past, travels forward into his future to meet the heroine. A successful time-travel romance must have the characters react logically to their experience and should investigate some of the differences, both physical and mental, between the world the character normally inhabits and the one where they landed. Some writers end their novels with the protagonists trapped in different time periods and unable to be together—to the displeasure of many readers of the genre.<ref name="timetravel">{{cite web|last=Marble|first=Anne M.|title=Writing Time Travel Romances|publisher=Writing-world.Com|date=September 2002|url=http://www.writing-world.com/columns/romance/marble05.shtml|accessdate=July 30, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070626181045/http://www.writing-world.com/columns/romance/marble05.shtml |archivedate = June 26, 2007}}</ref>
===Inspirational romance=== Inspirational romance, as the market exists today, combines explicitly [[Christian fiction|Christian]] themes with the development of a romantic relationship.<ref name="rwasub"/> In 2004, 167 novels were published in the inspirational romance subgenre.<ref name="rwastat"/> These novels typically do not include gratuitous violence or swearing, and the central courtship is chaste. Sex, if it is present at all, occurs after marriage and is not explicitly detailed. Many novels in this genre also focus on the hero or heroine's faith, turning the love story into "a triangle: the man and the woman and also their relationship with God."<ref name="duffy">{{Cite news | last = Duffy | first = Martha | title = The Almighty To The Rescue | newspaper = Time | date = November 13, 1995 | url =http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,983705,00.html | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref> Themes such as forgiveness, honesty, and fidelity are common.<ref name="layne">{{cite web | last = Layne | first = Sandy | title = Christian Romance Novels? | publisher = Write to Inspire | year = 2001 | url =http://www.writetoinspire.com/article1036.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007}}</ref>
The first line of series inspirational romances debuted shortly after the [[United States presidential election, 1980|1980 U.S. presidential election]], when Silhouette launched their Silhouette Inspirations line. The books were aimed at [[born-again Christian]]s and were marketed in religious bookstores. The Silhouette Inspirations line was closed after Harlequin acquired Silhouette in 1984 because it was not profitable.<ref>Thurston, pp 190–192.</ref> However, other Christian publishers continued to produce romance novels, including historical and contemporary, and Harlequin later rejoined the market with the 1998 launch of its Steeple Hill and Love Inspired lines.<ref>{{cite web|title=Love Inspired Facebook page|url=https://www.facebook.com/LoveInspiredBooks/info|accessdate=August 28, 2012}}</ref>
===Multicultural romance=== Multicultural romance typically features a hero and/or heroine who is [[African-American]], although some multicultural lines also include Asian or Hispanic heroes or heroines or [[Miscegenation|interracial]] relationships.<ref name="dunfordetal">{{Cite news|last=Dunford|first=Natalie|last2=Dyer|first2=Lucinda|last3=Holt|first3=Karen|last4=Rosen|first4=Judith|title=Toujours l'Amour|newspaper=Publishers Weekly|date=December 1, 2003|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA338936.html?industryid=23602&industry=Romance+Books&q=%22romance+novel%22|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071113130506/http://www.publishersweekly.com/article/CA338936.html?industryid=23602&industry=Romance+Books&q=%22romance+novel%22|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 13, 2007|accessdate=April 30, 2007|df=mdy-all}}</ref> The first line of multicultural romance novels, Arabesque, was launched by Kensington books in 1994. BET Books purchased the line in 1998, and the number of new authors that they publish has continued to expand each year. BET has also developed some of the Arabesque novels into made-for-television movies.<ref name="adlerstein">{{Cite news| last = Adlerstein| first = David | title = Multicultural Book Room| newspaper = South Florida Business Journal | date = September 8, 2000 | url =http://southflorida.bizjournals.com/southflorida/stories/2000/09/11/smallb1.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007}}</ref>
In 1999, Kensington Publishing launched the first line of Latino romance novels - ENCANTO. The ENCANTO novels were originally released in two ways - a bilingual Spanish/English version and a Spanish only version. Two novels were published every month until late 2001, when the line went into hiatus. Despite the demise of the line, several of the ENCANTO authors have continued writing novels with Latino protagonists namely, Sylvia Mendoza, Tracy Montoya, Caridad Pineiro, Berta Platas, Lara Rios and Lynda Sandoval.
Although romance novels featuring African-Americans and Hispanic protagonists are becoming more popular, those featuring Asian or Asian-American characters are rare. Author [[Tess Gerritsen]] believes this is due to the fact that there are fewer Asian-American women who read romances: "We read romances because we want to feel good about love...in order to do that, the reader must identify with the heroine."<ref name="nguyen">{{Cite news | last = Nguyen | first = Lan| title = The Color of Romance | newspaper =Audrey Magazine | date = September 2005 | url =http://www.audreymagazine.com/Sep2005/Living03.asp| accessdate = April 30, 2007 | format = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070406210723/http://www.audreymagazine.com/Sep2005/Living03.asp |archivedate = April 6, 2007}}</ref>
===Erotic romance=== {{Main article|Erotic romance novels}}
Erotic romance is a blend of romance and [[erotica]]. Erotic romance novels are characterized by strong sexual content, but can contain elements of any of the other romance subgenres. Erotic romance novels tend to use more frank language, avoiding many of the euphemisms used in books with milder content. These novels also usually include more sex scenes, often focusing more on the sex act rather than being a more traditional love scene, and may include more unusual positions or acts.<ref name="marbleerotic"/> Despite a greater emphasis on the sex scenes, however, erotic romance is distinguishable from traditional [[pornography]]. Pornography concentrates on the sex acts, but erotic novels include well-developed characters and a plot that could exist without the sex acts.<ref name="cooperposey">{{cite web|last=Cooper-Posey|first=Tracy|title=An End to Euphemisms: Is Erotica Right for You?|publisher=Writing-world.Com|year=2004|url=http://www.writing-world.com/romance/romantica.shtml|accessdate=July 30, 2007}}</ref>
Erotic romances' lengths run from short stories to single-title novels. Some of these are published as part of a category, such as Harlequin Blaze, while others are published as part of an anthology and are only [[novella]] length. Even single-title erotic romances may be as short as a novella, however.<ref name="marbleerotic">{{cite web|last=Marble|first=Anne M.|title=Getting to Know the Erotic Romance Field|publisher=Writing-World.Com|date=January 2005|url=http://www.writing-world.com/columns/romance/marble23.shtml|accessdate=July 30, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070211135434/http://www.writing-world.com/columns/romance/marble23.shtml |archivedate = February 11, 2007}}</ref>
Many of the publishers of erotic romance are either [[small press]] publishers or [[electronic book]] publishers. Writers often have more leeway as to what types of erotic acts can be included when working with an electronic publisher than they would have when working with a print publisher.<ref name=marbleerotic/> The market for erotic romances has been growing rapidly, leading some publishers to create new lines for these types of books.<ref name="avonred">{{cite web | title = Avon Red | publisher = [[Avon (publishers)]] | url =http://www.harpercollins.com/imprints/index.aspx?imprintid=518015| accessdate = May 11, 2008}}</ref> Some subjects are still considered taboo, even with erotic romance. Themes such as pedophilia, incest, and bestiality are discouraged by all publishers.<ref name="marbleerotic"/>
The market for erotic romances has grown rapidly. [[Ellora's Cave]], an electronic publisher that focuses on erotic romance, became the first electronic publisher recognized by the Romance Writers of America as a legitimate publisher.<ref name="cooperposey"/>
==Markets==
===North America=== The romance fiction market "has been impervious to the overall economic recession, with faithful readers spending up to $40 a month" on romance novels in 1982.<ref name="nyt1982"> {{Cite news | title = Expanding Romance Market | newspaper = [[New York Times]] | date = March 8, 1982 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/08/business/expanding-romance-market.html |accessdate = May 24, 2007}}</ref> That year, paperback romances totaled $300 million in sales, and the total audience was estimated at 20 million readers. A survey of 600 regular romance readers the same year "found that they mirror the general population in age, education, and marital and socioeconomic status." Over half of the women had at least some college education, and 40% were employed full-time. 60% of the women surveyed read at least one romance every two days. The women admitted to reading romances as an antidote to stress, for mental escape, and to learn about history and new careers.<ref name="thurstonnewspaper">{{Cite news | last =Thurston | first =Carol | title =The Liberation of Pulp Romances | newspaper =Psychology Today | date =April 1983 | format =PDF | url =http://www.cherylclarke.net/cherylclarke.net%20folder/cherylclarke.net/pdf_files/Binder%2011.pdf | accessdate =May 24, 2007 | deadurl =yes | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070712042917/http://www.cherylclarke.net/cherylclarke.net%20folder/cherylclarke.net/pdf_files/Binder%2011.pdf | archivedate =July 12, 2007 | df =mdy-all }}</ref>
{{asof|1982}} at least 25% of all paperbacks were romance novels;<ref name="mcdowell19820110">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/10/books/the-paperback-evolution.html |title=The Paperback Evolution |last=McDowell |first=Edwin |date=1982-01-10 |work=The New York Times |access-date=2018-03-15 |page=7 |language=en}}</ref> by 1991, they comprised 46% of all mass market paperbacks sold in the US. This expansion was due in part to voracious readers, with over half of Harlequin's customers purchasing 30 novels per month. By this time, the romance novel audience had become more educated, with 45% having a college degree, and more than half of the audience worked outside the home.<ref name="linden">{{Cite news | last = Linden | first = Dana Wechsler | last2 = Rees | first2 = Matt | title = I'm Hungry But Not For Food | newspaper = [[Forbes]] | date = June 6, 1922 | format = PDF | url = http://www.cherylclarke.net/cherylclarke.net%20folder/cherylclarke.net/pdf_files/Binder%204.pdf | accessdate = May 24, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070712042909/http://www.cherylclarke.net/cherylclarke.net%20folder/cherylclarke.net/pdf_files/Binder%204.pdf | archivedate = July 12, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
By the 2000s, romance had become the most popular genre in modern literature. In 2008, romantic fiction generated $1.37 billion in sales, with 7,311 romance novels published and making up 13.5% of the consumer book market. Over 74 million people claimed to have read at least one romance novel in 2008, according to a Romance Writers of America study. The study reported that 9.5% of romance readers identified themselves as male, and that romance readers were more likely to be married or living with a partner. According to the RWA 84% of romance buyers were women and 16% were men.<ref>http://www.rwa.org/p/cm/ld/fid=582</ref> Of the entire American population, 24.6% read at least one romance novel in 2008.<ref name="rwastat">{{cite web | title = Readership Statistics | publisher = [[Romance Writers of America]] | year = 2008 | url =http://www.rwanational.org/cs/readership_stats | accessdate = July 23, 2010|format=PDF}}</ref>
===International markets=== {{rquote|right|Along with cowboys and horses, the authors were told to skip ethnic heroes [for European readers] and not to let family members steal too much of the limelight. "But secret babies sell quite well, as do marriages of convenience, or arranged marriages and, of course, alpha heroes," Stoecker said.|''The New York Times'', 2004{{r|povoledo}}}} 74.8 million people read an English-language romance novel in 2008.{{r|ogas20110430}} Harlequin sells more than 4 books per second, half of them internationally. Author [[Heather Graham Pozzessere|Heather Graham]] attributes this to the fact that "emotions translate easily."<ref name="larsen">{{cite web | last = Larsen | first = Kristin | title = Romance Writers are Passionate About Their Work | publisher =Voice of America | date = August 9, 2005 | url =http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2005-08/2005-08-09-voa26.cfm?CFID=70475929&CFTOKEN=58000274| archive-url =http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20080916010627/http://voanews.com/english/archive/2005-08/2005-08-09-voa26.cfm| dead-url =yes| archive-date =September 16, 2008| accessdate = April 30, 2007 }}</ref> In the United Kingdom, over 20% of all fiction books sold each year are romance novels.<ref name="cambridge">{{Cite news|title=Labour of love a boon for Mary|date=June 14, 2007|newspaper=Cambridge Evening News|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/features/2007/06/14/356f5561-3b3a-49b5-ab9a-234b592b7f84.lpf|accessdate=July 19, 2007|format=|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070703222725/http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/news/features/2007/06/14/356f5561-3b3a-49b5-ab9a-234b592b7f84.lpf |archivedate = July 3, 2007}}</ref>
Although romance novels are translated into over 90 languages,<ref name="zaitchik"/> the majority of authors of these works are from Great Britain, the United States, Canada or, to a lesser extent, Australia.<ref name="povoledo"/> In France, where over 12 million romance novels are sold each year, all are translations.<ref name="zaitchik"/> and some publishing companies in Germany refuse to allow their romance authors to use their own names, fearing that the German audience will not buy a romance novel that does not have an Anglo-American pseudonym.<ref name="povoledo"/>
The [[English people|Anglo-Saxon]] perspective in the fiction at times can be much less successful in a European market. Although Italy is the strongest foreign market for the chick lit sold by single-title imprint Red Dress Ink, in that country romance readers do not care to read books about [[cowboy]]s, as this type of occupation was not common in their culture. The paranormal romance genre is not popular in countries such as Poland and Russia, although historical romance tends to be very successful.<ref name="povoledo">{{Cite news | last = Povoledo | first = Elisabetta | title = Women's Fiction for Europe: 'No cowboys, no babies' | newspaper = ''The New York Times'' | date = October 18, 2004 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/18/business/worldbusiness/18iht-books18_ed3_.html?_r=1 | accessdate = April 23, 2007}}</ref> Inspirational romance does not sell well in Europe, where romances that feature babies are very popular.<ref name="zaitchik">{{Cite news| last = Zaitchik | first = Alexander | title = The Romance Writers of America convention is just super | newspaper =New York Press | date = July 22, 2003 | url =http://nypress.com/its-nothing-but-love-at-the-romance-writers-of-america-convention/ | accessdate = April 30, 2007}}</ref> German readers enjoy reading more erotic romance novels,<ref name="povoledo"/> and some German translations of English romance novels expand or insert love scenes into otherwise tame stories. The alternate scenario also occurs, as other German translators censor the love scenes.<ref name="fritsche">{{cite web | last = Fritsche | first = Vivien | title = Impressions from a Romance Reader Overseas | publisher = All About Romance | date = July 1999 | url = http://www.likesbooks.com/vivien.html | accessdate = April 23, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070413090226/http://www.likesbooks.com/vivien.html | archivedate = April 13, 2007 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
As of 2014, romance is the most popular literary genre in Russia (chosen 13% of respondents), especially among the younger audience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://russia-rating.ru/info/2221.html|title=What do we read?|date=June 4, 2014|publisher=The Rating Center|language=Russian|accessdate=31 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2004, sales of romance novels in Australia increased 28% over the year before. Between 1999 and 2004 there was an increase of 40–50% in the number of new titles released. Harlequin received 20,000 unsolicited manuscripts each year.<ref name="bantick">{{Cite news | last = Bantick | first = Christopher| title = A Quiver Through the Bookshelves | newspaper =[[The Age]] | date = February 13, 2004 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/02/12/1076548158948.html | accessdate = April 30, 2007 | location=Melbourne}}</ref>
==Awards== {{Further|Romance Writers of America#Awards}} The most prestigious and notable awards for romance novels are the [[RITA Award]]s, which are presented annually by the [[Romance Writers of America]] to the best novels in romantic fiction.<ref>[http://www.slco.lib.ut.us/rita.htm Romance Writers of America RITA Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100113041339/http://www.slco.lib.ut.us/rita.htm |date=January 13, 2010 }}</ref>

The '''semantic view of theories''' is a position in the [[philosophy of science]] that holds that a scientific theory can be identified with a collection of [[model theory|models]]. The semantic view of theories was originally proposed by [[Patrick Suppes]] in “A Comparison of the Meaning and Uses of Models in Mathematics and the Empirical Sciences”Suppes, P. (1960), “A Comparison of the Meaning and Uses of Models in Mathematics and the Empirical Sciences,” Synthese 12: 287-301. as a reaction against the [[received view of theories]] popular among the [[Logical positivism| logical positivists]]. Many varieties of the semantic view propose identifying theories with a class of set-theoretic models in the [[Alfred Tarski|Tarskian]] sense,Suppes, P. (1960) and da Costa, Newton C. A., and Steven French (1990), “The Model-Theoretic Approach in the Philosophy of Science”, Philosophy of Science 57: 248–265. while others specify models in the mathematical language stipulated by the field of which the theory is a member.van Fraassen, Bas C. (1980), The Scientific Image. Oxford: Clarendon. and Suppe, Frederick (1989), The Semantic Conception of Theories and Scientific Realism. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. ==Semantic vs. syntactic views of theories== The semantic view is typically contrasted with the '''syntactic view of theories''' of the logical positivists and logical empiricists, especially [[Carl Gustav Hempel]] and [[Rudolf Carnap]]. On the contrast between syntactic and semantic views, [[Bas van Fraassen]] writes:
The syntactic picture of a theory identifies it with a body of theorems, stated in one particular language chosen for the expression of that theory. This should be contrasted with the alternative of presenting a theory in the first instance by identifying a class of structures as its models. In this second, semantic, approach the language used to express the theory is neither basic nor unique; the same class of structures could well be described in radically different ways, each with its own limitations. The models occupy central stage.van Fraassen B. 1980. ''The Scientific Image''. Oxford University Press, p. 44.
In this same book, van Fraassen, a key founder of the semantic view of theories, critiques the syntactic view in very strong terms:
Perhaps the worst consequence of the syntactic approach was the way it focused attention on philosophically irrelevant technical questions. It is hard not to conclude that those discussions of axiomatizability in restricted vocabularies, 'theoretical terms', Craig’s theorem, 'reduction sentences', 'empirical languages', Ramsey and Carnap sentences, were one and all off the mark—solutions to purely self-generated problems, and philosophically irrelevant. (p. 56)
The semantic view of theories has been extended to other domains, including population genetics.[[Elisabeth Lloyd|Lloyd, EA]]. 1994. ''The Structure and Confirmation of Evolutionary Theory. Princeton University Press. ==See also== *[[Structuralism (philosophy of science)]] *[[Frederick Suppe]] ==Notes== ==External links== * [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.567.7077&rep=rep1&type=pdf "The Semantic View of Theories: Models and Misconceptions"] [[Category:Metatheory of science]] {{philo-stub}}
